required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Efficacy of a Toothpaste in Providing Relief From the Pain of Dentinal Hypersensitivity
clinical_study.official_title: A Clinical Study Investigating the Efficacy of a Dentifrice in Providing Short Term Relief From Dentinal Hypersensitivity

brief_summary.textblock: A study to compare the efficacy of a test dentifrice against a control dentifrice in reducing dentinal hypersensitivity over a two week treatment period.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Evaporative Air Sensitivity Pain Response on a Schiff Sensitivity Scale at Day 14
primary_outcome.description: Response to a constant jet of air applied to hypersensitive teeth is evaluated using a Schiff Sensitivity pain response scale. According to this analog scale, pain response for each individual stimulated tooth ranged from 0 to 3; 0 - participant does not respond to air stimulation, 1 - participant responds to air stimulus but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2 - participant responds to air stimulus and request discontinuation of stimulus, 3 - participant responds to air stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful and request discontinuation of stimulus. Those teeth that met the tactile threshold inclusion criterion (tactile threshold ≤ 20g) were assessed at baseline and Day 14. The Investigator directed a second application of air from a standard dental syringe to the facial surface of the two sensitive teeth selected at baseline. The Schiff Sensitivity Score was calculated as the subject level mean change (on two teeth) from baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Evaporative Air Sensitivity Pain Response on a Schiff Sensitivity Scale Immediately Post-treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to immediately post treatment administration
secondary_outcome.description: Response to a constant jet of air applied to hypersensitive teeth is evaluated using a Schiff Sensitivity pain response scale. According to this analog scale, pain response for each individual stimulated tooth ranged from 0 to 3; 0 - participant does not respond to air stimulation, 1 - participant responds to air stimulus but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2 - participant responds to air stimulus and request discontinuation of stimulus, 3 - participant responds to air stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful and request discontinuation of stimulus. Those teeth that met the tactile threshold inclusion criterion (tactile threshold ≤ 20g) were assessed at baseline and immediately after treatment. The Investigator directed a second application of air from a standard dental syringe to the facial surface of the two sensitive teeth selected at baseline. The Schiff Sensitivity Score was calculated as the subject level mean change (on two teeth) from baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Evaporative Air Sensitivity Pain Response on a Schiff Sensitivity Scale at Day 3
secondary_outcome.description: Response to a constant jet of air applied to hypersensitive teeth is evaluated using a Schiff Sensitivity pain response scale. According to this analog scale, pain response for each individual stimulated tooth ranged from 0 to 3; 0 - participant does not respond to air stimulation, 1 - participant responds to air stimulus but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2 - participant responds to air stimulus and request discontinuation of stimulus, 3 - participant responds to air stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful and request discontinuation of stimulus. Those teeth that met the tactile threshold inclusion criterion (tactile threshold ≤ 20g) were assessed at baseline and Day 3. The Investigator directed a second application of air from a standard dental syringe to the facial surface of the two sensitive teeth selected at baseline. The Schiff Sensitivity Score was calculated as the subject level mean change (on two teeth) from baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Tactile Pain Threshold Score at Day 14
secondary_outcome.description: The Response to increasing force on hypersensitive teeth was evaluated using a Yeaple Probe pain response scale (10g to 80g). According to this tactile sensitivity assessment, an increasing force is applied to hypersensitive tooth until a yes response to pain is recorded or the maximum force has been reached. Tactile testing begins with a force of 10g and it is increased by 10g, with each successive challenge, until either a "yes" response is recorded or the maximum force (80g) is reached. An increase in tactile score from baseline represents an improvement in sensitivity

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Tactile Pain Threshold Score at Day 3
secondary_outcome.description: The Response to increasing force on hypersensitive teeth was evaluated using a Yeaple Probe pain response scale (10g to 80g). According to this tactile sensitivity assessment, an increasing force is applied to hypersensitive tooth until a yes response to pain is recorded or the maximum force has been reached. Tactile testing begins with a force of 10g and it is increased by 10g, with each successive challenge, until either a "yes" response is recorded or the maximum force (80g) is reached. An increase in tactile score from baseline represents an improvement in sensitivity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Tactile Pain Threshold Score Immediately Post-treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to immediately post treatment administration
secondary_outcome.description: The Response to increasing force on hypersensitive teeth was evaluated using a Yeaple Probe pain response scale (10g to 80g). According to this tactile sensitivity assessment, an increasing force is applied to hypersensitive tooth until a yes response to pain is recorded or the maximum force has been reached. Tactile testing begins with a force of 10g and it is increased by 10g, with each successive challenge, until either a "yes" response is recorded or the maximum force (80g) is reached. An increase in tactile score from baseline represents an improvement in sensitivity.

criteria.textblock: - Subjects who suffer from tooth sensitivity.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were recruited at the clinical site.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Of 126 participants screened, 9 participants did not meet the study criteria, 3 were lost to follow up and 1 withdrew consent before randomization. Remaining 113 participants were randomized to study treatments.

group.title: Stannous Fluoride (SnF) Dentifrice
group.description: Participants brushed each of the 2 selected sensitive teeth for 30 seconds each, followed by the whole mouth with 1 inch strip of the test dentifrice (0.454% SnF) for at least 1 minute and rinsing with 5mL of water.

group.title: Sodium Monofluorophosphate (NaMFP) Dentifrice
group.description: Participants brushed whole mouth with 1-inch strip of the control dentifrice (0.76% Sodium Monofluorophosphate [NaMFP]) for one timed minute, followed by rinsing with 5 mL of water.

group.title: SnF Dentifrice
group.description: Participants brushed each of the 2 selected sensitive teeth for 30 seconds each, followed by the whole mouth with 1 inch strip of the test dentifrice (0.454% SnF) for at least 1 minute and rinsing with 5mL of water.

group.title: NaMFP Dentifrice
group.description: Participants brushed whole mouth with 1-inch strip of the control dentifrice (0.76% NaMFP) for one timed minute, followed by rinsing with 5 mL of water.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Evaporative Air Sensitivity Pain Response on a Schiff Sensitivity Scale at Day 14
outcome.description: Response to a constant jet of air applied to hypersensitive teeth is evaluated using a Schiff Sensitivity pain response scale. According to this analog scale, pain response for each individual stimulated tooth ranged from 0 to 3; 0 - participant does not respond to air stimulation, 1 - participant responds to air stimulus but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2 – participant responds to air stimulus and request discontinuation of stimulus, 3 – participant responds to air stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful and request discontinuation of stimulus. Those teeth that met the tactile threshold inclusion criterion (tactile threshold ≤ 20g) were assessed at baseline and Day 14. The Investigator directed a second application of air from a standard dental syringe to the facial surface of the two sensitive teeth selected at baseline. The Schiff Sensitivity Score was calculated as the subject level mean change (on two teeth) from baseline.
outcome.population: Intent To Treat (ITT) population: All randomized participants, who were administered with at least one study treatment during the study and provided at least one post-baseline assessment of efficacy.

group.title: SnF Dentifrice
group.description: Participants brushed each of the 2 selected sensitive teeth for 30 seconds each, followed by the whole mouth with 1 inch strip of the test dentifrice (0.454% SnF) for at least 1 minute and rinsing with 5mL of water.

group.title: NaMFP Dentifrice
group.description: Participants brushed whole mouth with 1-inch strip of the control dentifrice (0.76% NaMFP) for one timed minute, followed by rinsing with 5 mL of water.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Evaporative Air Sensitivity Pain Response on a Schiff Sensitivity Scale at Day 14
measure.description: Response to a constant jet of air applied to hypersensitive teeth is evaluated using a Schiff Sensitivity pain response scale. According to this analog scale, pain response for each individual stimulated tooth ranged from 0 to 3; 0 - participant does not respond to air stimulation, 1 - participant responds to air stimulus but does not request discontinuation of stimulus, 2 – participant responds to air stimulus and request discontinuation of stimulus, 3 – participant responds to air stimulus, considers stimulus to be painful and request discontinuation of stimulus. Those teeth that met the tactile threshold inclusion criterion (tactile threshold ≤ 20g) were assessed at baseline and Day 14. The Investigator directed a second application of air from a standard dental syringe to the facial surface of the two sensitive teeth selected at baseline. The Schiff Sensitivity Score was calculated as the subject level mean change (on two teeth) from baseline.
measure.population: Intent To Treat (ITT) population: All randomized participants, who were administered with at least one study treatment during the study and provided at least one post-baseline assessment of efficacy.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis considered change from baseline to be same for both treatments.
analysis.p_value_desc: No adjustment made for multiple comparisons, as primary comparison was pre-specified.
analysis.method_desc: ANCOVA with treatment as fixed factor and baseline Schiff Score as covariate.
analysis.estimate_desc: Difference is 0.454% SnF minus 0.76% NaMFP such that a negative difference favours first named treatment.

reported_events.time_frame: All adverse events encountered or spontaneously reported following administration of any investigational product, or for up to 5 days after the last administration of investigational product were recorded.

group.title: SnF Dentifrice
group.description: Participants brushed each of the 2 selected sensitive teeth for 30 seconds each, followed by the whole mouth with 1 inch strip of the test dentifrice (0.454% SnF) for at least 1 minute and rinsing with 5mL of water.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: GSK agreements may vary with individual investigators, but will not prohibit any investigator from publishing. GSK supports the publication of results from all centers of a multi-center trial but requests that reports based on single-site data not precede the primary publication of the entire clinical trial.
